ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
HDB 3-ROOM PURCHASE FLATS
(Number unsold and conversion into bigger flats)


    1. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development what is the number of 3-room purchase flats which are not taken up as at the latest convenient date; and what plans are being made to convert these flats to enhance their take-up.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 30th April 1989, there are 10,900 unsold 3-room flats. Out of these, 3,300 units will be converted into bigger flats.

    The remaining 7,600 3-room flats will not be converted and are being offered for sale. There are presently 1,710 applicants on the waiting list for 3-room flats. The HDB has ceased further construction of 3-room flats for sale.

Column: 235

MEASURES TO CURB ROAD USAGE


    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Amendment [29th May, 1989] to Question [29th May, 1989],

Column: 236



    "That this House supports the principles underlying the latest measures introduced by the Ministry of Communications and Information to curb road usage." - [Dr Hong Hai].

    Which Amendment was,

    'at the end, to add -

    "but regrets that some of the measures are too hastily introduced and too harsh; and that this House urges the Ministry to review them.".' - [Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam].

    Question again proposed, "That the words proposed to be added, be there added."

     Mr Lew Syn Pau (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, this debate on our land transport policy would not be complete if I do not give this House the feedback of the taxi operators on the issue. At this point I would like to declare my interest again as the General Manager of NTUC Comfort.

    When I last addressed this House on this subject in January the taxi drivers were still reeling from the sudden hefty increase in taxi diesel tax in November last year from $1,100 to $4,400, an increase of $3,300 or 300%. This increase translated to a cost increase of $10 per working day. Since then the Public Transport Council approved only a 20 cents increase in flagged-down fare. Six months after the fare increase, daily collections have gone up only marginally - $2 in the case of single shift taxi drivers and $6 for two-shift

Column: 237

taxis. In the same period, however, operating costs have gone up further because the price of diesel fuel has gone up in November last year from 34.2 cents to 42.9 cents per litre, an increase of 8.7 cents per litre or a percentage increase of 25%. This works out to an increase of about $3 per day for two-shift taxis. The net result therefore is that two-shift taxi drivers are still $7 worse off per day compared to pre-November 1988.

    Before enough time has been given for taxi drivers to recover fully they are now again hit by the recent measures announced by the Government to curb the usage of cars. There are two particular measures which hit them directly. The first one is the HDB car park fee increase from $25 to $50, an increase of 100%. This would translate to an increase of about another $1 a day for the taxi drivers. This increase is unnecessary at this time because this measure does not curb usage of taxis or cars at all. It only adds to the burden of the lower income car owners and taxi drivers who drive for a living.

    The second measure that will affect taxi drivers adversely is the increase in the Area Licence Fee for taxis from $2 to $3. This increase will reduce the number of commuters riding into the CBD in taxis in the morning. This will not reduce congestion caused by taxis because the number of taxis on the road is fixed in the short and medium term. Instead of driving into the CBD with commuters, these taxis will now just be causing congestion on the ring roads, as they ply around looking for passengers. In the afternoon the same thing will happen. There will be congestion again on the ring roads but a shortage of taxis in the CBD. Alternatively, the taxi drivers can buy the season CBD pass but this will raise the operational cost, again by another $2 per day but without any prospect of return.

    Since taxis are public vehicles, just like buses and MRT, I would like to urge the Government to retain the ALS fee for taxis at $2. I would also like to take this opportunity to urge the Government to review the taxi diesel tax increase scheduled for November this year.

Column: 238



    In conclusion, I would like to point out to the House that the recent measures to curb road usage together with the diesel tax increase have resulted in a drop in income by about 10% for taxi drivers since November last year. This setback is happening at a time when politicians, civil servants and many other workers are having salary increases and pay adjustments. From the taxi drivers' point of view, therefore, these measures are too harsh and they come too fast.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the amendment to the motion.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Industry and the Minister for the Environment (Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng): Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, allow me to seize this opportunity to thank the Ministry of Communications and Information for all the good things they have done for our transport system. Sir, it has always been my stand that as a Member of the Frontbench, I would leave it to the Backbench to question Government policies. However, you do get that odd moment when you see a policy sticking out like a sore thumb giving the impression that it was not carefully thought through and has the net effect of affecting certain quarters of the population and rather unfairly too. Not to speak up under such circumstances can be construed to mean irresponsibility on my part. Sir, I therefore rise to support the amendment of the Member for Fengshan. Although I do support the idea of Dr Hong Hai and some of my other colleagues in this House, I cannot support Dr Hong Hai's motion as it is directionless and if we adopt it, we will be going all over the place and be more confused. Sir, I submit the interim measures to control the growth of the car population will affect many of my constituents rather unfairly. Please allow me to explain.

    First, the change in car pool policy. My constituency is not fortunate as some others are into which the MRT runs, or where it is easy to get on to the MRT line. In certain areas, you cannot even hop into a bus and hope to travel to a place directly in that bus. You may have to hop into a bus, take a little detour somewhere, hop into another before you get to your desti-

Column: 239

nation. I am attempting to demonstrate that for certain people in certain parts of Singapore, the public transport system is still less than perfect, and it is exactly for the people living in these areas that I am speaking up for, ie, my friends and my constituents in Mountbatten.

    Sir, we were the ones who came out some years ago to encourage Singaporeans to car pool. Singaporeans, being cooperative, willing listeners, sensible, obliged and car pooled where possible. Now we are withdrawing this exemption for cars with four persons to travel free into the CBD. Question: are we letting Singaporeans down? How can we expect them to give us full cooperation the next time?

    Sir, in withdrawing the exemption, the Ministry gives the reason that they want to encourage greater use of public transport and that the people who were picked up for car pooling were actually bus commuters. But, as I have said earlier on, Sir, unless the public transport system works for as many people, ie, it is as convenient for any one person to travel from Point A, as it is for another to travel from Point B, as it is for another to travel from Point C, and so on, then to withdraw that exemption may be considered quite unfair. Unless the system is improved, you cannot do that.

    That is the reason why in my constituency people simply walk across the road, hop into a car that wants to get into the CBD with four persons free, and goes to where he wants to go. They have found a good solution, Sir, with a little more convenience and comfort to work. Let it be. After all, it is still the same person transporting his own body to the place where he wants to go without buying a car. Why should he be pushed into a bus or an MRT against his convenience? The more ways people have to go to work, the less people will need to depend on one system. In this way, we reduce the inconvenience by giving people many choices and I thought the MCI espoused the thinking that the more people pay, the less each pays. Similarly, the more ways to go to a place, the less the inconvenience. By the way, in the evening, a person is further inconvenienced by not being able to car pool back home. This is one example of

Column: 240

how we can affect some people's lives through a reversal of a policy which had hitherto worked quite well for many people. I wonder whether there are many other ways where other people around Singapore are being affected by this same reversal of policy.

    Then you have the increase in HDB car park charges. In increasing HDB car park charges, we need to be a little considerate. Sir, the increase paid by a person with a low income is more painful than that paid by a person with a higher income. Thus, to increase car park charges in HDB estates so steeply and across the board is not entirely fair. The person who lives in a 5-room flat or a maissonnette finds it less painful than a person who lives in a 3-room flat. Dr Hong Hai used the term "the appendage that does not belong" to describe the unusual event of increasing by 100% the HDB car park charges. To me, it is the appendage that was there which had become an "appendix". The surgeon in MCI has now used his sharp scalpel to remove the unwanted appendix. In discussing the increase in HDB car park charges, I am not even thinking of the "painlessness" felt by those who are currently residing in private homes and condominiums. Why? Because I am well aware of the fact that our civil servants these days have a famous dictum, ie, "front end", "back end" charges. I wonder if they have the "middle end" charge.

    Sir, there is another poser. The person who lives in a 3-room flat may want to drive his family around during weekends to enjoy himself or he may just be someone who needs a car for his work . He may be a salesman in a small firm whose company does not provide a car but requires him to have a car before he can get the job. There are advertisements to this effect in the press occasionally. So how do we make 2 and 2 add up to 4? By the way, it is going to cost more too to visit friends and relatives in HDB estates over the week and I expect in due course the Member for Ayer Rajah will ask the Minister for National Development whether he will allow free parking in HDB estates for sons and daughters who want to visit their parents during the week.

Column: 241



    So, Sir, what is the net effect of just these two measures, meaning the change in car pool policy and the increase in HDB car park charges? The net effect is that those who can well afford a car will be happy. No doubt the 5-room flatter has to pay increased HDB car park charges but he is more than compensated for in reduced CBD charges. Those who need a car but are borderline cases, they drop their cars. Up to now, it may not be so bad. But when he has to resort to the motorcycle because he has to be up early and be in time for work, he not only faces increased charges but exposes himself to greater traffic dangers and the weather. If he resorts to the bus or the MRT, he may face greater inconvenience and having to rise very early to catch the bus or the MRT in time while many others are still resting happily at home.

    Sir, I therefore submit that although we need to control car growth in Singapore, the measures so far announced are not equitable and I would suggest that the Ministry spend a bit more time to reconsider them. Don't let us keep the car to the private homedwellers and the 5-room flatters, and the bus or the MRT to the 4-roomers and below. Have a system that enables greater mobility and more choice.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun (Hong Kah GRC)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday the Member for Fengshan following Dr Hong Hai's motion supporting the principles in curbing road usage by vehicles added an amendment expressing regrets that some of the measures are too hastily introduced and too harsh and urged the Members and the relevant Ministry to reconsider. I do not agree to this proposed amendment. The reason is very simple. I am not objecting to his request for review of these measures by the Ministry. I feel that he should not say that the Government in implementing the various measures has been too hasty. I am one of the Members of the GPC on communications and information. I know that the recent plan and measures on road transport by the Government have been taken after careful thought and long consideration and implemented without choice

Column: 242

but to run the dissatisfaction of the public. It is really hard on the Government with all its good intentions. The problems of road transport are just like those of Home Affairs. They are very difficult to tackle. I am very sure that our people do not mean that they just want the ministry to do nothing but allowing cars and road use to increase without restriction, because in the end when there is serious congestion on the roads and when road traffic is paralysed, then it will not be good to any body. While the Government must necessarily and actively take positive measures in good time to regulate and improve the public transportation system to make it more comfortable, convenient, and attractive for car owners to travel by it, the Ministry of Communications has also to take some measures at the same time to prevent the worsening of the conditions of road traffic.

    Dr Beng had also said that certain measures taken are too harsh. It is a matter of subjective view which varies from person to person. My stand is there are two of the recently announced measures we may consider alleviating. The first item, the increase in season car parkingfees in HDB carparks from $25 to $50 can be implemented in two stages so that it will lighten the burden of the car owning HDB estate dwellers have time to plan in advance.

    The second item is about the evening ALS. Because it may cause more congestion along major ring roads, adversely affect CBD retail businesses and cause the residents inconvenience, I feel the Government should delay implementing the measure and allow the increase in CBD parking charges to work and reduce the increasing evening congestion in the city for the time being. Thank you, Mr. Speaker.

     Dr Hong Hai (Bedok GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, I listened eagerly to the speeches by the Members for Fengshan and Ayer Rajah who proposed and seconded the amendment to my motion, and I thought that they would be taking a different line from the rest of us who supported the original motion standing in my name. I was pleasantly surprised that they said more or less the same things, that the principles

Column: 243

behind the Ministry's measures were correct but that the specific measures were controversial and should be reviewed.

    Sir, that being the case, I see the amendment as unnecessary. As I have explained in the House yesterday, it is perfectly consistent to support the original motion while disagreeing with some of the specific measures. Indeed, this is what Members of my GPC as well as the Feedback Chairman have done. So why the need for an amendment?

    Sir, the Member for Fengshan has made the interesting claim that only the amended motion can lead to action while the original motion is just "talk". If there is a possibility that this is the case, I would be the first to support the amendment. But the fact of the matter is that both the original motion and the amended motion allow Members to ask the Minister to reconsider specific measures; neither motion can bind the Minister to any action. I would imagine that the Minister is more likely to be persuaded by sound argument than by fire and brimstone.

    Sir, I would have readily supported the amendment but for the fact that it describes the measures as too harsh and too hasty. To disagree with a measure like the evening ALS is one matter. To call it too harsh is quite another. More important, I think, is whether or not the measure will work to reduce congestion and whether the cost is worth the benefit. That is really the issue.

    Sir, I do not think it is fair to call the measures too hasty. I know for a fact that the Minister for Communications and Information spent a great deal of time with his officials researching the subject, discussing it with my GPC and other MPs, and presenting it to Cabinet. We may have honest differences in judgment with the Minister and we may like him to research some issues further. But he is the decision-maker and he must judge for himself when to take a decision and when to act.

    Sir, I disagree with the amendment also because it is negative in stance. It emphasizes only those measures that are not supported. What about those measures that are supportable? You cannot have the cake and eat it. If we want smooth traffic,

Column: 244

we must make some sacrifices. As any medical doctor can tell you, good medicine is often bitter.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Not necessarily.

     Dr Hong Hai: Often bitter. The key word is "often", Sir.

    Sir, some of the measures are quite sound. I personally would endorse, for example, higher parking charges in the city, the extension of the ALS requirement to goods and commercial vehicles and the elimination of exemption for car pooling. These are not popular measures but, in my view, they are necessary. The Minister has had the courage to take an unpopular stand.

    In answer to the Senior Parliamentary Secretary who thought that the motion was directionless, this is the direction of the motion - follow the principles, the measures must match the principles. This was the substance of the motion. I confess that it is a subtlety and it may have escaped some, including the Senior Parliamentary Secretary. If a man of his intellectual calibre can miss it, then I readily concede the necessity to be more explicit.

    Sir, the debate so far has made it clear to our GPC that there is a need for the issues involved to be discussed further publicly, so that opinions and expert views from a broad spectrum of people can be collated to help the Ministry review its policies and plan better ones. The First Deputy Prime Minister has previously mooted the idea of GPCs holding public hearings on important issues. Sir, I believe that land transportation today is an issue deserving such attention. I am, therefore, proposing to the Minister that such hearings be held in the near future. Should these hearings be held in the future, I would be pleased to invite the Members for Fengshan and Ayer Rajah to be co-opted into a GPC Sub-Committee which will conduct the hearings. Both Members have vast amounts of experience and expertise to offer, particularly Dr Beng who was formerly Chairman of the GPC on Communications and Information.

    In the meantime, Sir, I urge Members of the House to press on with their suggestions and criticisms relating to the new

Column: 245

measures introduced to curb car usage. We trust that the Minister will view these suggestions positively, make changes where he feels appropriate and review the measures again after the public hearings are held.

    Sir, for reasons stated earlier, and as much as I respect Dr Tan Cheng Bock's wisdom and sincerity and Dr Beng's political acumen, I am regretfully unable to support the amendment.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Point of clarification.

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock: Dr Hong Hai mentioned that the motion is almost similar to his. But his motion supports MCI's policies in principle, which Dr Beng and I also support. But the amendment goes beyond that. It seeks also to reflect the people's feelings and unhappiness over some of the issues, like evening ALS, increased HDB parking fees to 100%. To many, these are inappropriate measures. The two motions are therefore different. His motion is conciliatory. The amendment motion is more realistic, more in tune with the people's feelings. So MPs in this House must not be swayed by his rhetoric and must let conscience be their guide.

     Dr Hong Hai: Mr Speaker, Sir, I stand by what I said earlier. The motion's direction is that the principles have to be supported and that the measures must match the principles. My objection to the amendment is that it emphasizes only those measures that are not supportable. It focuses attention on harshness and hastiness. It says nothing about positive measures, and there are many positive measures in the package. Therefore, the amended motion is unbalanced. My motion, as it stands, says we support the principles and leave it open to the House to comment on and criticize specific measures, some of which are supportable and some of which may not be.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam: Mr Speaker, Sir, in response to Dr Hong Hai that we have not supported ---

Column: 246



     Mr Speaker: Dr Arthur Beng, you cannot respond to the speech of Dr Hong Hai. If you want to make a brief clarification, I will allow that.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam: Yes, Sir, I want to make a clarification.

     Mr Speaker: But no speeches.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kin Lam: The amendment says, "some of the measures" and not all the measures.

     Mr Speaker: All right. Mr Ng.

     Mr Ng Pock Too (Nee Soon Central): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move an amendment to the amendment moved by Dr Arthur Beng.

    To leave out all the words after "measures", and insert -

    'may be too onerous and urges the Ministry to review them.'

    [Copy of amendment to the amendment handed to the Clerk.]

    Sir, my colleagues who have spoken before me have expressed their sentiments. There is one common thread that runs through all their arguments in this debate. The policy of restraining car ownership and car usage is necessary. But the measures which have been announced are unnecessarily harsh and, by implication, completely devoid of feelings of compassion for car owners and road users. So they make the earnest appeal for a reprieve, for that palliative which car owners can tolerate and live with. Even though I was one of the scheduled speakers to join in the chorus of appeals to implore the Minister to treat our car owners and road users with a gentler glove, I was quite prepared to let the other speakers who are more passionate in their arguments than myself to undertake this task. But when I heard my colleague, the Member for Fengshan, move and speak on his amendment to the motion being debated, I felt compelled to speak against his amendment, and to move this amendment to his amendment.

    The Member went on an emotional tirade to castigate the Ministry for being too hasty and too harsh in introducing some of the measures and called for a review of these measures. But he forgot to

Column: 247

identify what these measures were. Which specific measures was he referring to when he said that they were too hastily introduced?

    The Member, as every Member knows, was the previous Chairman of the GPC for Communications and Information. This appointment gave him the privilege of full access to information on Singapore's road transport policies which the Ministry has been working on over the past few years. The Minister for Communications and Information had also given a series of fair warning over the past six months on the Ministry's intentions to curb car usage through stiffer measures. To now say that these measures were too hastily introduced would suggest that these were on the spur-of-the-moment decisions, and not given the thorough consideration that they deserve. Please remember that all these decisions and policies have to pass the test by going through Cabinet. A hasty decision poorly thought through can never stand Cabinet's test.

    Are the measures too harsh? It is really subjective. What is harsh to some may be interpreted as mild to others. These are buzz words. They mean different things to different people. The need to review? Yes, I agree with him. The measures are somewhat burdensome on some of our road users. But a review has to be carefully thought through. Perhaps a better time to do the review could be after the Ministry has had the chance to assess the results of these measures.

    What are we really after? We are after effective solutions that can deal with a real problem, where tough measures are necessary to solve our traffic problems. We are not interested in making any passionate oration here in Parliament to sidestep the real issue.

    As a Backbench MP, I speak up for the Ministry, because it has a difficult job to do. I do not envy the Minister's task. The Minister for Communications and Information has never been a popular portfolio. I know it hurts every car owner's pockets, having to pay more for car park charges. I know it is unpleasant having to endure more restrictions because of changes in the ALS scheme. I know it is bothersome

Column: 248

for all motorcyclists to buy ALS stickers if they want to enter the CBD during the peak hours. But unless we have the political will and understanding to tackle a difficult problem before us, this debate will be nothing more than mere airing of grouses. I am not saying that the Ministry has the right answer to solve the problem. I reserve that judgment. Only time can tell whether the measures announced are effective. But if all of us speak up against these measures with no suggestion for a better alternative, because it is a popular thing to do in Parliament, then we have not really addressed our minds to the real problem. I urge all Members to allow the Ministry an even chance of succeeding in working its policy through. The end objective is what we all desire to see, a better managed traffic situation on our small island nation.

    Listening to the Member for Fengshan yesterday reminded me of a patient being prescribed the proverbial bitter pill. The package of measures announced is indeed a bitter pill for all of us to swallow. But though bitter, it has the potency to cure our traffic ills. In asking for a review, what the Member is trying to do, by implying that these measures were hastily introduced and are too harsh for our roadusers, is to tell the doctor, "Now, take this pill back, make it less bitter, sugar-coat it if necessary. Never mind if the pill is less effective or takes a longer time to have the desired effect." Can we live with the ailment? Can we in Singapore, where the traffic situation is reaching saturation point on some of our roads?

    In moving my amendment to the amendment I mentioned that some of the measures were onerous and that they needed review by the Ministry. One of these measures which I feel very strongly about is the 100% increase in the seasonal car parking charges. I would like to ask the Minister for National Development, on what basis did he arrive at a 100% increase in car parking charges? Do we have full cost recovery with a 100% increase?
